Derek, I agree that it's interesting to question the mechanism and 
even th=
e justification behind "protecting innovation."  Certainly 
such declaratio=
ns can become dogma if they are repeated enough and 
we should continually =
scrutinize them to prevent that.

However, I am not completely sure what yo=
u are suggesting because 
I'm not sure how you classify an individual as "e=
volutionarily
younger?"  Isn't every individual evolutionarily descended fr=
om the 
first generation and therefore all equivalent in this respect?  

W=
hile I may not understand the proposed remedy, part of your 
argument was p=
hilosophical in terms of what speciation really means, 
and I see where you=
 are coming from on that.  Yet I do believe that 
what is going on in NEAT =
is justifiably analogous to natural 
speciation in the way that you questio=
n.  While you point out that 
everyone in NEAT is competing on the same fit=
ness function and 
therefore it is not really like nature, I would disagree=
.  In 
nature, there is also only one fitness function, which is "to 
repro=
duce."  All species are just variations on ways of getting that 
done.  In =
analogy, all species in NEAT are variations on ways of 
getting done whatev=
er it is the fitness function requires.  
A "niche" in this sense means an =
alternate means to accomplish a 
task, which is an idea well suited to diff=
erent topologies and 
weights that do the same thing in different ways.

I =
also do not fully understand the assertion that "All chromosomes
in NEAT ca=
n potentially mate with one another."  NEAT was highly 
influenced by the c=
ompeting conventions problem, which had been a 
known pathology in neuroevo=
lution for many years.  It was perhaps 
the worst of all problems with such=
 sustems.  The problem is of 
course exacerbated by differing topologies as=
 well as weights.  The 
competing conventions problem is actually a very de=
ep problem 
because there are indeed inviduals that have no hope of mating =

effectively, which is evidenced all over nature.  A bird and pig 
will nev=
er yield a flying pig, even through some kind of artificial 
insemination o=
r chimeric hybridization.  They should simply not be 
mating with each othe=
r (since it would waste precious evaluations 
from a computational standpoi=
nt, not to mention the ethical 
disaster).  

It was well known that enormo=
us damage was being inflicted in non-
speciated neuroevolving populations w=
herein similar bird-pig-like 
mating events were happening routinely.  Thus=
, just because one can 
align genes optimally does not mean one should if s=
pecies have 
diverged too far afield.

In any case, it is probably wise to =
question the precise mechanisms 
through which NEAT accomplishes or aims to=
 accomplish these ends, 
and I would not be surprised if competitive altern=
atives arise.  
However, I do still believe that the underlying motivations=
 make 
good sense.

ken



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Derek James" <djam=
es@...> wrote:
>
> NEAT uses speciation, according to Ken, for two reasons:=
 protecting
> innovation and "preventing incompatible genes from crossing o=
ver" 
(from his
> dissertation). Though it seems to me the first reason is =

emphasized and
> presumably the most important. Is this correct?
> 
> The =
second reason doesn't seem particularly well-justified. All 
chromosomes
> =
in NEAT can potentially mate with one another. I understand the 
idea of
> =
niching, but in biological terms it means that organisms can 
survive and
>=
 reproduce by exploiting different resources. In a fitness function 
where =
all
> the individuals are performing the same task, e.g. pole balancing, 
t=
his
> analogy doesn't seem to hold. The networks might be using different
>=
 strategies, but this seems to be more analogous to two individuals 
in the=

> same species fighting for the same niche.
> 
> Anyway, if protecting inn=
ovation really is the prime motivation for
> speciation, why not use a simp=
ler mechanism? I was thinking of 
just keeping
> the population unspeciated=
, and giving a fitness bonus to 
evolutionarily
> younger individuals. This=
 would be a lot less complex than 
speciating the
> population, and wouldn'=
t it essentially accomplish the same thing, 
in terms
> of giving innovatio=
ns a chance to prove themselves by making them
> competitive with older ind=
ividuals?
> 
> Has this sort of strategy been used before? And if so, how d=
oes it 
compare?
> If not, why wouldn't it work as well to protect innovati=
on?
> 
> --Derek
>
